Location: Nossa Senhora do Cabo Shipwreck, Nosy Boraha (Île Sainte-Marie)
Recommended Reason: 1721 Portuguese treasure ship captured by pirates, estimated $138 million value with gold, silver, diamonds, emeralds and rubies confirmed by 16 years of archaeological work
Supporting Evidence: Over 3,300 artifacts recovered including gold coins with Arabic writing, porcelain, religious artifacts. Captured by Olivier 'The Buzzard' Levasseur

Location: Olivier Levasseur's Treasure Cache, Nosy Boraha
Recommended Reason: Famous pirate 'La Buse' threw cryptogram to crowd before execution in 1730 stating 'My treasures for who will understand!' - treasure never found
Supporting Evidence: Historical execution records, cryptogram exists, Levasseur involved in multiple major pirate raids including Nossa Senhora do Cabo

Location: Captain Kidd's Adventure Galley, Baie Ambodifotatra
Recommended Reason: William Kidd's ship Adventure Galley found in 2001, historically documented treasure burial site that inspired Stevenson's Treasure Island
Supporting Evidence: Wreck discovered in 2001 in Port Sainte-Marie, historical accounts of Kidd choosing to hide treasures and sink vessel here

Recommended Reason: Authentic pirate cemetery with skull and crossbones tombstone, burial site for pirates who accumulated vast wealth during Golden Age of Piracy
Supporting Evidence: Authentic cemetery with recognizable pirate symbols, tombstones with skull and crossbones epitaphs, accessible at low tide

Location: Bay of Forbans Multiple Shipwrecks, Nosy Boraha
Recommended Reason: Dozens of authentic pirate ships still lie in bay, 7-10 ships intentionally sunk or wrecked during height of piracy, at least 4 confirmed pirate vessels
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological surveys identified multiple overlapping ballast piles, estimated 7-10 wrecks from Golden Age of Piracy period

Recommended Reason: Operating base of legendary pirate John Avery (Henry Every), one of most successful pirates in history with massive treasure hauls
Supporting Evidence: Historical records confirm Avery used Sainte-Marie as base, known for capturing Mughal treasure ships worth millions

Recommended Reason: Base of pirate Christopher Condent who captured Portuguese ship with 150,000 pieces of eight, used island for rest and treasure storage
Supporting Evidence: Historical records of Condent's operations from Sainte-Marie, major captures including Portuguese vessels with significant treasure

Recommended Reason: Base of Thomas Tew, pirate known for extremely successful Red Sea operations and massive treasure hauls from Mughal ships
Supporting Evidence: Historical documentation of Tew's use of Sainte-Marie as base, successful pirate career with documented major captures

Location: Secondary Treasure Ships, Nosy Boraha Harbor
Recommended Reason: Multiple additional pirate ships and captured prizes beyond Nossa Senhora do Cabo, site described as common scuttling location for prize ships
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological research indicates numerous prize ships were taken to area to be scuttled after capture, overlapping ballast piles from different periods

Location: Golden Age Trading Post Ruins, Nosy Boraha
Recommended Reason: Remnants of 17th-18th century trading posts where pirates exchanged loot for supplies, potential cached goods and hidden valuables
Supporting Evidence: Island provided secret hiding spots, freshwater, fruit and meat for pirates, established trading relationships with local population
